factoid: Pierre had an unsolved problem that tormented Pierre.
The unsolved problem was caused by hints given by the princess, who was Pierre's cousin, at Moscow, concerning Dólokhov’s intimacy with Pierre's wife.
The unsolved problem was also caused by an anonymous letter Pierre had received that morning.
The anonymous letter said that Pierre saw badly through his spectacles.
The anonymous letter said that Pierre's wife's connection with Dólokhov was a secret to no one but Pierre.
Pierre absolutely disbelieved the princess' hints.
Pierre absolutely disbelieved the anonymous letter.
Pierre feared looking at Dólokhov.
Dólokhov was sitting opposite Pierre.
When Pierre met Dólokhov’s handsome insolent eyes, Pierre felt something terrible and monstrous rising in his soul.
Pierre turned quickly away when he met Dólokhov’s handsome insolent eyes.
Pierre involuntarily recalled his wife's past and her relations with Dólokhov.
Pierre saw clearly that what was said in the letter might be true.
Pierre saw clearly that what was said in the letter might at least seem to be true had it not referred to his wife.
Dólokhov had fully recovered his former position after the campaign.
Dólokhov had returned to Petersburg.
Dólokhov had come to Pierre.
Dólokhov availed himself of his friendly relations with Pierre as a boon companion.
Dólokhov had come straight to Pierre's house.
Pierre put Dólokhov up at his house.
Pierre lent Dólokhov money.
Hélène had smilingly expressed disapproval of Dólokhov’s living at Pierre's house.
Dólokhov cynically praised Pierre's wife's beauty to Pierre.
From that time until they came to Moscow, Dólokhov had not left Pierre and Hélène for a day.
Pierre thought that Dólokhov is very handsome.
Pierre thought that Pierre knows Dólokhov.
Pierre thought that it would be particularly pleasant to Dólokhov to dishonor Pierre's name and ridicule Pierre.
Pierre thought that it would be pleasant to Dólokhov to deceive Pierre if it were true.
Pierre thought that Pierre does not believe the letter.
Pierre thought that Pierre has no right to believe the letter.
Dólokhov assumed an expression of cruelty when tying a policeman to a bear and dropping them into water.
Dólokhov assumed an expression of cruelty when challenging a man to a duel without any reason.
Dólokhov assumed an expression of cruelty when shooting a post-boy’s horse with a pistol.
That expression was often on Dólokhov’s face when looking at Pierre.
Pierre thought that Dólokhov is a bully.
Pierre thought that killing a man means nothing to Dólokhov.
Pierre thought that Dólokhov thinks everyone is afraid of Pierre.
Pierre thought that Dólokhov thinks that Pierre is afraid of Pierre.
Pierre thought that Pierre is afraid of Dólokhov.
Pierre again felt something terrible and monstrous rising in his soul.
Dólokhov, Denísov, and Rostóv were sitting opposite Pierre.
Dólokhov, Denísov, and Rostóv seemed very gay.
Rostóv was talking merrily to his two friends.
One of Rostóv's friends was a dashing hussar.
The other of Rostóv's friends was a notorious duelist and rake.
Rostóv occasionally glanced ironi­cally at Pierre.
Pierre had a preoccupied, absent-minded, and massive figure.
Pierre's figure was very noticeable at the dinner.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre because Pierre appeared to his hussar eyes as a rich civilian.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre because Pierre appeared to him as the husband of a beauty.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre because Pierre appeared to him as an old woman.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre because Pierre had not recognized Rostóv.
Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre because Pierre had not responded to Rostóv's greeting.
The Emperor’s health was drunk.
Pierre, lost in thought, did not rise or lift his glass.
Rostóv shouted "What are you about?" at Pierre.
Rostóv looked at Pierre in an ecstasy of exasperation.
Rostóv said "Don’t you hear it’s His Majesty the Emperor’s health?" at Pierre.
Pierre sighed.
Pierre rose submissively.
Pierre emptied his glass.
Pierre waited until all were seated again.
Pierre turned with his kindly smile to Rostóv.
Pierre said "Why, I didn’t recognize you!" to Rostóv.
Rostóv was otherwise engaged.
Rostóv was shouting "Hurrah!" at the dinner.
Dólokhov said "Why don’t you renew the acquaintance?" to Rostóv.
Rostóv said "Confound him, he’s a fool!" to Dólokhov.
Denísov said "One should make up to the husbands of pretty women."
Pierre did not catch what they were saying.
Pierre knew they were talking about him.
Pierre reddened.
Pierre turned away.
Dólokhov said "Well, now to the health of handsome women!" to Pierre.
Dólokhov had a serious expression.
Dólokhov had a smile lurking at the corners of his mouth.
Dólokhov turned with his glass to Pierre.
